holdings.text: It is not necessary to consider whether the Income-tax Officer was competent to issue a notice under s. 34 of the Income-tax Act for the years 1947-48 and 1950-51, for in our view the property received by the appellant was not remuneration given to her by Sita Devi for services rendered or to be rendered by her.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to consider whether the Income-tax Officer was competent to issue a notice under s. 34 of the Income-tax Act for the years 1947-48 and 1950-51, for in our view the property received by the appella

holdings.reasoning_summary: Primary finding that receipts not income renders s.34 issue moot.

holdings.text: By ss. 3 & 4 the Act imposes a general liability to tax upon all income. But the Act does not provide that whatever is received by a person must be regarded as income liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: By ss. 3 4 the Act imposes a general liability to tax upon all income. But the Act does not provide that whatever is received by a person must be regarded as income liable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation limits scope of 'income' under charging sections.

holdings.text: In all cases in which a receipt is sought to be taxed as income, the burden lies upon the Department to prove that it is within the taxing provision. Where however a receipt is of the nature of income, the burden of proving that it is not taxable because it falls within an exemption provided by the Act lies upon the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In all cases in which a receipt is sought to be taxed as income, the burden lies upon the Department to prove that it is within the taxing provision. Where however a receipt is of the nature of income, the burden of proving,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes general taxability burden from exemption claims; corrects High Court's misplacement of onus.

holdings.text: The decision of this Court in the Commissioner of Income-tax v. Calcutta Agency Ltd. lends no support to the proposition which the High Court has enunciated.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in the Commissioner of Income-tax ... v. Calcutta Agency Ltd. lends no support ... That was a case in which the taxpayer was claiming under s. 10 2 xv allowance ... the burden lay upon the taxpayer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedent as limited to claims for business expenditure allowance under s.10(2)(xv).

holdings.text: There is ample authority for the position that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amount of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature. But these observations cannot be read divorced from their context.

anchor.surface_text: There is ample authority ... that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amount of cash received ... the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms precedent (Govindarajulu) but limits to cases of undisclosed source; inapplicable here as source disclosed.

holdings.text: But in this case the source of the income was disclosed by the appellant, and there was no dispute about the truth of that disclosure.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Source (gifts from Sita Devi) admitted and undisputed, preventing adverse inference.

holdings.text: The Tribunal rightly observed that the information collected by the Department from different sources which consisted of record of ex parte statements ... could have no value in establishing the case of the Department.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex parte statements lack evidentiary value without cross-examination.

holdings.text: But these circumstances could not establish that what was given to her by Sita Devi was remuneration for services rendered or to be rendered.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Local agent role and 'Private Secretary' description create suspicion only, insufficient proof of remuneration.

holdings.text: The conclusion of the Tribunal is, therefore, based on matters which may at the highest create some suspicion, and upon its view that the burden of proving that the receipts were not taxable lay upon the appellant. But a conclusion recorded by the Tribunal by wrongly throwing the burden of proof upon the assessee cannot be regarded as binding upon the High Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal finding vitiated by legal error on burden; not binding in reference.

holdings.text: On the first part of the two questions it must be recorded that what the assessee received in the relevant years of account was not assessable to tax.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Department failed burden; evidence insufficient to prove remuneration over gift claim.
